---
title: "Kit Installation Guide"
description: "Learn how to install kits from npm, JSR, GitHub, and local sources with smart source resolution"
---

## Overview

Hypergen kits can be installed from multiple sources using the `hypergen kit install` command. The CLI automatically detects the source type and uses the appropriate installation method:

- **NPM/JSR packages** → Installed to `node_modules/` using your package manager
- **GitHub/GitLab/Git repos** → Downloaded to `.hyper/kits/` using tiged (no git history)
- **Local paths** → Copied to `.hyper/kits/`
- **Tarball URLs** → Downloaded and extracted to `.hyper/kits/`

All installations are tracked in `.hyper/kits/manifest.json` for version management and reproducibility.

## Quick Start

```bash
# Install from npm
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs

# Install from GitHub (shorthand)
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs

# Install from local path
hypergen kit install ./my-local-kit
```

## Source Resolution

Hypergen uses intelligent source resolution to determine where to install kits from. You don't need to specify prefixes in most cases—the CLI automatically detects the source type.

### Resolution Priority

The CLI resolves kit sources in the following order:

1. **Explicit Prefixes** (highest priority)
2. **Registry-Specific Patterns**
3. **Local Paths** (Unix and Windows)
4. **Git URLs**
5. **GitHub Shorthand**
6. **NPM Packages** (default)

## Installation Sources

### NPM Packages

Install kits from the npm registry:

```bash
# Scoped package
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs

# Unscoped package
hypergen kit install my-kit

# Specific version
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs@1.2.0

# Version range
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs@^1.0.0
```

### JSR (JavaScript Registry)

Install from the [JSR registry](https://jsr.io):

```bash
# Using jsr: prefix
hypergen kit install jsr:@std/path

# Using @jsr/ pattern (auto-detected)
hypergen kit install @jsr/std__path
```

<Note>
Bun supports JSR natively. For npm/pnpm/yarn, Hypergen uses `npx jsr add` automatically.
</Note>

### GitHub

Install kits directly from GitHub repositories:

```bash
# Shorthand (auto-detected)
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs

# With branch
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs#develop

# With tag
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs@v1.0.0

# Explicit prefix
hypergen kit install github:svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs

# Full Git URL
hypergen kit install https://github.com/svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs.git
```

<Tip>
The `user/repo` pattern is automatically detected as GitHub. No prefix needed!
</Tip>

<Info>
**Installation Location**: GitHub kits are downloaded to `.hyper/kits/` without git history using [tiged](https://github.com/tiged/tiged) - faster and cleaner than `git clone`.
</Info>

### GitLab

Install from GitLab repositories:

```bash
# Explicit prefix
hypergen kit install gitlab:username/my-kit

# Full Git URL
hypergen kit install https://gitlab.com/username/my-kit.git
```

### Bitbucket

Install from Bitbucket repositories:

```bash
hypergen kit install bitbucket:username/my-kit
```

### Local Paths

Install kits from your local filesystem:

#### Unix/macOS Paths

```bash
# Relative path
hypergen kit install ./my-local-kit
hypergen kit install ../sibling-kit

# Absolute path
hypergen kit install /absolute/path/to/kit

# Home directory
hypergen kit install ~/projects/my-kit

# With file: prefix
hypergen kit install file:./my-local-kit
```

#### Windows Paths

```bash
# Drive letter (backslash)
hypergen kit install C:\Projects\my-kit

# Drive letter (forward slash)
hypergen kit install C:/Projects/my-kit

# Relative path
hypergen kit install .\my-local-kit
hypergen kit install ..\sibling-kit

# UNC path
hypergen kit install \\server\share\kit
```

<Note>
Windows paths are automatically detected—no prefix needed for drive letters or UNC paths.
</Note>

### Git URLs

Install from any Git repository:

```bash
# HTTPS
hypergen kit install https://example.com/repo.git

# Git protocol
hypergen kit install git://example.com/repo.git

# SSH
hypergen kit install git+ssh://git@example.com/repo.git

# With git+ prefix
hypergen kit install git+https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

<Info>
URLs ending in `.git` are automatically treated as Git repositories.
</Info>

### Tarball URLs

Install from hosted tarball files:

```bash
hypergen kit install https://example.com/my-kit-1.0.0.tgz
```

## Installation Destinations

Kits are installed to different locations based on their source type:

### NPM/JSR Packages → `node_modules/`

```bash
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs
# Installed to: node_modules/@hyper-kits/nextjs/

hypergen kit install jsr:@std/path
# Installed to: node_modules/@jsr/std__path/
```

Managed by your package manager (bun, npm, pnpm, yarn) and tracked in `package.json`.

### GitHub/Git Sources → `.hyper/kits/`

```bash
hypergen kit install hyper-kits/nextjs
# Downloaded to: .hyper/kits/nextjs/

hypergen kit install user/repo#develop
# Downloaded to: .hyper/kits/repo/
```

Downloaded using [tiged](https://github.com/tiged/tiged) - no `.git` directory, just clean template files.

### Local Paths → `.hyper/kits/`

```bash
hypergen kit install ./my-local-kit
# Copied to: .hyper/kits/my-local-kit/

hypergen kit install ../sibling-kit --name custom
# Copied to: .hyper/kits/custom/
```

Files are copied (excluding `node_modules/`, `.git/`, `dist/`, `build/`).

## Kit Manifest Tracking

All installed kits (except npm/JSR packages) are tracked in `.hyper/kits/manifest.json`:

```json
{
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "kits": {
    "nextjs": {
      "name": "nextjs",
      "source": "hyper-kits/nextjs#main",
      "type": "github",
      "installedAt": "2026-02-13T14:23:15.944Z",
      "version": "0.1.0",
      "branch": "main"
    }
  }
}
```

**Tracked Information**:
- Kit name and source
- Installation timestamp
- Version (from `package.json`)
- Git branch/tag (if applicable)
- Source type

**Benefits**:
- Prevent duplicate installations
- Track kit versions
- Enable reproducible environments
- Audit trail of installations

## Installation Options

### Custom Kit Name

Override the auto-detected kit name:

```bash
hypergen kit install hyper-kits/nextjs --name my-nextjs
# Installed to: .hyper/kits/my-nextjs/
```

### Development Dependency

Install npm/JSR packages as dev dependencies:

```bash
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs --dev
```

<Note>
The `--dev` flag only applies to npm/JSR packages. Kits installed to `.hyper/kits/` are not added to `package.json`.
</Note>

### Working Directory

Install in a specific project:

```bash
hypergen kit install hyper-kits/nextjs --cwd /path/to/project
```

The kit will be installed to `/path/to/project/.hyper/kits/nextjs/` (or the nearest parent with `package.json`).

## Package Manager Detection

Hypergen automatically detects your project's package manager by checking for lock files:

| Lock File | Package Manager |
|-----------|----------------|
| `bun.lockb` or `bun.lock` | Bun |
| `pnpm-lock.yaml` | pnpm |
| `yarn.lock` | Yarn |
| `package-lock.json` | npm |

<Tip>
If no lock file is found, Hypergen defaults to npm.
</Tip>

## Examples

### Install Multiple Kits

```bash
# Install from different sources
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-react
hypergen kit install ./kits/custom-kit --dev
```

### Install Specific Versions

```bash
# NPM version syntax
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs@1.2.3
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs@^1.0.0
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs@latest

# GitHub tags
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs@v1.0.0

# GitHub branches
hypergen kit install svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs#develop
```

### Development Workflow

```bash
# Use local kit during development
hypergen kit install ../my-kit-in-progress

# Install published version for production
hypergen kit install @my-org/my-kit
```

### Check Installed Kits

View the manifest to see all installed kits:

```bash
cat .hyper/kits/manifest.json
```

Or list kit directories:

```bash
ls -la .hyper/kits/
```

## Source Resolution Examples

Here's how different inputs are resolved:

| Input | Type | Resolved Source |
|-------|------|----------------|
| `@hyper-kits/nextjs` | npm | `@hyper-kits/nextjs` |
| `svallory/hypergen-kit` | github | `github:svallory/hypergen-kit` |
| `jsr:@std/path` | jsr | `jsr:@std/path` |
| `./my-kit` | local | `./my-kit` |
| `C:\Projects\kit` | local | `C:\Projects\kit` |
| `~/kits/my-kit` | local | `~/kits/my-kit` |
| `https://github.com/user/repo.git` | git | `https://github.com/user/repo.git` |
| `github:user/repo` | github | `github:user/repo` |
| `user/repo@v1.0.0` | github | `github:user/repo@v1.0.0` |
| `@scope/pkg@^2.0.0` | npm | `@scope/pkg@^2.0.0` |

## Project Structure

After installing kits, your project structure will look like:

```
my-project/
├── package.json
├── node_modules/
│   └── @hyper-kits/         # NPM kits
│       └── nextjs/
├── .hyper/
│   └── kits/
│       ├── manifest.json    # Installation tracking
│       ├── my-custom-kit/   # GitHub/local kits
│       └── another-kit/
└── src/
```

**Key Directories**:
- `.hyper/kits/` - GitHub, GitLab, local kits (tracked in manifest.json)
- `node_modules/` - NPM/JSR packages (tracked in package.json)

## Troubleshooting

### Kit Already Exists

```
Error: Kit already exists: nextjs
Remove it first with: rm -rf .hyper/kits/nextjs
Or specify a different name with: --name <name>
```

**Solution**: Either remove the existing kit or use `--name` to install with a different name:

```bash
# Remove existing kit
rm -rf .hyper/kits/nextjs

# Or install with different name
hypergen kit install hyper-kits/nextjs --name nextjs-v2
```

### Kit Not Found

If you get a "Kit not found" error:

1. **NPM/JSR**: Verify the package name is correct on the registry
2. **GitHub**: Check if the repository exists and is public
3. **Private repos**: Ensure you're authenticated (`gh auth login`)
4. **Local paths**: Verify the path exists and is accessible

```bash
# Verify npm package exists
npm view @hyper-kits/nextjs

# Verify GitHub repo exists
gh repo view svallory/hypergen-kit-nextjs
```

### Package Manager Not Found

If you get "Package manager not found":

```bash
# Install bun (recommended)
curl -fsSL https://bun.sh/install | bash

# Or install pnpm
npm install -g pnpm

# Or install yarn
npm install -g yarn
```

### Permission Errors

For global installations, you may need elevated permissions:

```bash
# Unix/macOS
sudo hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs -g

# Windows (run as Administrator)
hypergen kit install @hyper-kits/nextjs -g
```

### Path Resolution Issues

**Windows users**: If you have issues with paths containing spaces:

```bash
# Wrap in quotes
hypergen kit install "C:\Program Files\my-kit"

# Or use forward slashes
hypergen kit install "C:/Program Files/my-kit"
```

**Unix users**: Escape spaces or use quotes:

```bash
hypergen kit install ./my\ kit
hypergen kit install "./my kit"
```

## Security

Hypergen validates all kit sources to prevent command injection:

- Shell metacharacters (`;`, `|`, `` ` ``, `$`, etc.) are rejected
- Sources are properly escaped before execution
- Only valid package manager commands are used

<Warning>
Only install kits from trusted sources. Installing malicious kits could compromise your system.
</Warning>
